Description: Political uncertainty over the U.S. debt ceiling led to a government shutdown and market volatility with the S&P 500 dropping ~4%.
The Federal Reserve signaled it might reduce its bond-buying program (quantitative easing) leading to a sharp rise in bond yields and a temporary S&P 500 dip.
Global markets including the S&P 500 experienced a sharp selloff due to concerns over China’s economic slowdown and falling oil prices. The S&P 500 dropped over 10%.
The S&P 500 entered a correction (down ~10%) due to rising interest rates trade tensions with China and fears of a slowing global economy.
The U.S. increased tariffs on Chinese goods escalating trade tensions leading to a ~6% drop in the S&P 500 in May 2019.
The S&P 500 peaked at 3386 before plummeting 34% by March 23 2020 due to the global spread of COVID-19 and lockdown measures.
West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude oil prices briefly turned negative due to oversupply and lack of storage capacity during the COVID-19 pandemic impacting energy markets.
U.S. unemployment spiked to 14.8% the highest since the Great Depression due to COVID-19 lockdowns.
The S&P 500 recovered to its pre-COVID peak closing above 3386 driven by stimulus measures and monetary policy support.
Inflation began rising sharply driven by supply chain disruptions stimulus spending and post-COVID demand recovery. CPI reached 5% by May 2021.
The U.S. passed a $1.2 trillion infrastructure bill boosting economic growth expectations and market sentiment.
The S&P 500 hit a record high of 4796 before inflationary pressures and Fed rate hikes led to a correction.
Russia’s invasion of Ukraine drove up energy and commodity prices exacerbating global inflation and contributing to market volatility.
The Federal Reserve began raising interest rates to combat inflation starting with a 25-basis-point hike eventually reaching 4.25%–4.5% by the end of 2022.
The S&P 500 entered a bear market falling 20% from its January peak due to inflation fears and Fed tightening. The index bottomed at 3577 on October 12 2022.
U.S. inflation (CPI) peaked at 9.1% the highest in 40 years prompting aggressive Fed rate hikes.
The S&P 500 closed at 4293 marking a 20% rally from its October 2022 low signaling the end of the bear market.
After a correction (down 10.3% from July to October 2023) the S&P 500 rebounded driven by cooling inflation and strong earnings.
The S&P 500 reached an all-time high gaining 4.5% year-to-date before entering a correction in early 2025.
The Fed cut rates by 25 basis points to a range of 4.25%–4.5% adopting a neutral stance as inflation eased.
